titleStmt.title: Mark Noble's frollick; who being stopp'd by the constable near the Tower, was examin'd where he had been; whither he was going; and his name and place where he dwelt: to which he answered, where the constable would have been glad to have been, and where he was going he dare not go for his ears; as likewise his name, which he call'd twenty shillings; with an account of what followed, and how he came off. To the tune of The new rant. Licensed according to order.

Mark Noble's frollick; who being stopp'd by the constable near the Tower, was examin'd where he had been; whither he was going; and his name and place where he dwelt: to which he answered, where the constable would have been glad to have been, and where he was going he dare not go for his ears; as likewise his name, which he call'd twenty shillings; with an account of what followed, and how he came off. To the tune of The new rant. Licensed according to order.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for P[hilip]. Brooksby, J[onah]. Deacon, J[osiah]. Blare, and J[ohn]. Back,

notesStmt.note: Verse: "One night at a very late hour ..."
Date, place of publication and publisher's names from Wing.
Reproduction of original in the Harvard University, Houghton Library.
